BC-MOVIES-IN-BRIEF-3TAKES-NYT 
NEW AND NOTEWORTHY MOVIES 

  (lh) 
 c.1999 N.Y. Times News Service   

   Here is a selective listing by critics of The New York Times of
new or noteworthy movies currently playing in theaters. Running
times and ratings of films are in parentheses.

   `AMERICAN PIE,' starring Jason Biggs, Chris Klein, Natasha
Lyonne, Thomas Ian Nicholas, Tara Reid, Mena Suvari and Eugene
Levy. Directed by Paul Weitz (R, 100 minutes). The snickering
teen-age comedy about four boys, all seniors in the same Michigan
high school, who make a pact to lose their virginity by the end of
the school year, serves up a new gross-out joke every five minutes.
The movie obviously wants to outdo ``There's Something About Mary''
in raunchy guffaws, but it lacks the antic spirit of its
forerunner. More like an upper-middle-class ``Porky's,'' it parades
its dirty jokes as crassly as an old-time burlesque show (Stephen
Holden).

   `ARLINGTON ROAD,' starring Jeff Bridges, Tim Robbins, Hope
Davis, Robert Gossett and Joan Cusack. Directed by Mark Pellington
(R, 117 minutes). In a smart, stylish thriller that recalls the
paranoid classics of the '70s, Bridges plays a history professor
who begins to suspect that his smiling suburban neighbors are not
what they seem. Tracking down clues to an anti-government terrorist
network, he also engages in a battle of wits with Robbins' cryptic
character, and these fine actors square off to gripping effect.
Swift and pulse-quickening, this thriller has more than its share
of surprising twists, including a whopper at the finale. All in
all, a welcome change of pace from the season's dopey blockbusters
(Janet Maslin).

   `AUSTIN POWERS: THE SPY WHO SHAGGED ME,' starring Mike Myers,
Heather Graham and Elizabeth Hurley. Directed by Jay Roach (PG-13,
95 minutes). There may come a time when even Austin Powers tires of
the words ``Oh, behave!'' But it isn't here yet. Although the
sequel with the fab title is several love beads short of its
predecessor and more than a few scenes play like outtakes, this is
still a crafty, intermittently hilarious comedy. Myers' neo-Sellers
multiple-personality act is fine even when the material is less so,
and this sequel makes the most of Dr. Evil, his most inspired
creation. A scatological Scotsman, the film's walking id and
bathroom joke, is more of an acquired taste. Costumes and pop
references are still a hoot, as is the adorably benighted Austin.
Ms. Graham makes terrific eye candy but doesn't share Ms. Hurley's
quick-witted air of being in on the joke (Maslin).

   `AUTUMN TALE,' starring Beatrice Romand, Marie Riviere, Didier
Sandre, Alain Libolt and Alexia Portal. Directed by Eric Rohmer
(PG, 110 minutes; in French with English subtitles). The final
chapter of the director's ``Tales of the Four Seasons'' is as
sublimely warming an experience as the autumn sun that shines
benevolently on the Rhone Valley vineyard owned by the central
character, Magali (Ms. Romand). The movie follows the adventures of
this wiry and vital but lonely widowed mother of two after she
allows two friends to play matchmaker. The film's plot, like that
of other Rohmer movies, is mathematically schematic as the
characters indulge in exquisitely verbalized soul-searching. As
sensuously gratifying as it is civilized, with a wonderful central
performance by Ms. Romand, it reaches a happy ending that feels
entirely earned (Holden).  

   `BIG DADDY,' starring Adam Sandler, Cole and Dylan Sprouse and
Joey Lauren Adams, Jon Stewart and Leslie Mann. Directed by Dennis
Dugan (PG-13, 95 minutes). It's awfully early in the career of Adam
Sandler to find him sharing the screen with a scene-stealing
6-year-old (actually the Sprouse twins). Besides, the cute kid in
Sandler's movies is usually the star himself. But he's in a
position to do whatever he likes, even if it's a flimsy sentimental
comedy with more product plugs and fewer laughs than might have
been hoped for. Having greatly expanded his following with the
romantic comedy and '80s kitsch of ``The Wedding Singer,'' not to
mention the inspired rustic lunacy of ``The Waterboy,'' he falls
back on much less inventive material this time. And the barrage of
brand-name junk food is enough to make skin break out in the
audience (Maslin).

   `THE BLAIR WITCH PROJECT,' starring Heather Donahue, Michael
Williams and Joshua Leonard. Directed by Daniel Myrick and Eduardo
Sanchez (R, 87 minutes). A horror film shot outdoors by its actors,
who play three scared filmmakers at work on a spooky documentary,
this is a fine example of how to make something out of nothing _
nothing but terrific imagination and a game plan so enterprising it
should elevate its creators to pin-up status at film schools
everywhere. With tentacles including a hit Web site, an elaborate
fake witch mythology, a book tie-in, a special on the Sci-Fi
Channel and much more, this clever little indie is at the center of
a new form of synergy and an inspired multimedia blitz (Maslin).

   `DEEP BLUE SEA,' starring Saffron Burrows, Thomas Jane, LL Cool
J, Jacqueline McKenzie, Michael Rapaport, Stellan Skarsgard and
Samuel L. Jackson, Directed by Renny Harlin (R, 100 minutes).
Better not mess with Mother Nature. That's the familiar message of
this man-against-shark horror film in which the research team of a
floating ocean laboratory is stalked by three 8,000-pound
genetically ``improved'' mako sharks. Ms. Burrows is the chilly,
anything-for-science marine biologist behind the research, and Jane
the hunky shark-wrangler who tends these razor-toothed killing
machines. ``Titanic'' meets ``Jaws,'' without romance, history,
myth or credible characters, only nonstop action and half an ocean
full of crimson, blood-thickened water (Holden).  

   `DICK,' starring Kirsten Dunst and Michelle Williams. Directed
by Andrew Fleming (PG-13, 90 minutes). Now we know the identity of
Deep Throat, the confidential source who gave the journalists Bob
Woodward and Carl Bernstein the inside dish about Richard Nixon's
role in the Watergate scandal and helped bring down his presidency.
``Dick'' reveals the snitches to have been two giggly 15-year-old
girls, Betsy (Ms. Dunst) and Arlene (Ms. Williams), whom Nixon had
appointed his official dog walkers. In remembering the good old
days of plumbers and White House tape recordings, this extended,
wildly funny ``Saturday Night Live''-style sketch spares no one.
Dan Hedaya's shifty-eyed, hunch-shouldered Nixon caricature is the
hilarious embodiment of paranoid guilt (Holden).  

   `DROP DEAD GORGEOUS,' starring Kirsten Dunst, Denise Richards
and Kirstie Alley. Directed by Michael Patrick Jann (PG-13, 97
minutes). In the guise of sending up beauty pageants, this
mean-spirited, clunky satire manages to load up on stereotypes,
sneer at Minnesota, stage a scene in which beauty contestants vomit
en masse and make its audience wince through what must be a record
number of miserably unfunny jokes. Ms. Dunst and Ms. Richards show
some stellar appeal despite the dreary circumstances. And Allison
Janney makes the most of a supporting role (Maslin).

   nn

   `EYES WIDE SHUT,' starring Tom Cruise and Nicole Kidman.
Directed by Stanley Kubrick (R, 145 minutes). This last cryptic,
spellbinding addition to the Kubrick canon provides a stunning
epiphany for the summer of the dirty joke. It's a dead-serious film
about eros and mortality, one that flirts with the ridiculous but
sustains its fundamental eeriness and gravity throughout. Cruise,
as a doctor caught up in a nighttime sexual odyssey of strange,
dreamlike clarity, and Ms. Kidman, as the wife who sparks his
jealousy by speaking frankly of her own libido, give themselves
over body and soul to the filmmaker's meticulous and delicately
balanced scheme. Given the dark themes and explicit nudity found
here, the R rating (achieved by digital alterations to 65 seconds'
worth of film) is a joke (Maslin).

   `THE GENERAL'S DAUGHTER,' starring John Travolta, Madeleine
Stowe, James Cromwell, Timothy Hutton and James Woods. Directed by
Simon West (R, 118 minutes). Murder on a military base was once
enough of a pretext for a detective thriller, but nowadays it takes
more. The prevailing sleaze quotient calls for kinks, and this
galling adaptation of a Nelson DeMille best seller is happy to
oblige. So the title character, a pretty young officer who the film
thinks has no place in the military, is the victim of a lurid
crime. Travolta and Ms. Stowe affably investigate whodunit, though
the unraveling of the crime is laughably arbitrary. The real point
of their ponderous investigation is that the victim asked for what
she got (Maslin).

   `THE HAUNTING,' starring Liam Neeson, Lili Taylor, Catherine
Zeta-Jones and Owen Wilson. Directed by Jan De Bont (PG-13, 117
minutes). In a wildly overdone haunted house with a Gothic Nouveau
Riche look, walls warp, statues morph and things go bump in the
night. The special effects are piled on so relentlessly that after
a while the sight of the flying cow from De Bont's ``Twister ``
would not be amiss. Firmly committed to the idea that more is more,
this is a remake of a 1963 black-and-white film that left much more
to the imagination. But the cast is good; Neeson plays the doctor
who leads the other three principals to Hill House for a psychology
experiment that goes really, really wrong (Maslin).

   `AN IDEAL HUSBAND,' starring Cate Blanchett, Minnie Driver,
Rupert Everett, Julianne Moore and Jeremy Northam. Written and
directed by Oliver Parker (PG-13, 97 minutes). The best thing about
Parker's likable but diluted screen adaptation of Oscar Wilde's
1895 comedy of politics and Victorian morality is Everett's
portrayal of Wilde's elegantly epigrammatic alter ego Lord Arthur
Goring. In underplaying this seemingly incorrigible (but actually
wise, witty and caring) rake, Everett makes him all the more
charming. Northam and Ms. Blanchett are well cast as a politician
and his priggish wife, but Ms. Moore and Ms. Driver miss hitting
the right notes in a screenplay that streamlines Wilde into a
quasi-contemporary style, keeping some but not all of the
playwright's scintillating bons mots. The settings are so lavish
they're almost edible (Holden).  

   `INSPECTOR GADGET,' starring Matthew Broderick and Rupert
Everett. Directed by David Kellogg (PG, 85 minutes). The midmorning
midden of children's cartoons that yielded a vein of cinematic gold
with ``George of the Jungle'' has now been mined for this clinker.
Too bad, because this Disney comedy wastes good talent. Broderick
brings an endearing combination of intelligence, wit and naivete to
his portrayal of a security guard who is transformed into the human
gizmo, Inspector Gadget, after being blown up in an effort to
capture a megalomaniacal magnate (Everett). But even Broderick can
go only so far with the film's noisy, childish material. Watching
this movie is like watching a human Swiss Army knife for nearly an
hour and a half. It's a remarkable device, but do you really want
to spend a lot of time with a not-too-bright hardware store
Frankenstein creation that can light cigars with his thumb, shoot a
grappling hook to the top of a skyscraper and produce a helicopter
from his head? (Lawrence Van Gelder).  

   `LAKE PLACID,' starring Bill Pullman, Bridget Fonda, Oliver
Platt and Brendan Gleeson. Written by David E. Kelley and directed
by Steve Miner (R, 88 minutes). Despite the DOA nature of the genre
it tacitly sends up, this ``Jaws''-minded demon crocodile movie
finds a fair amount to work with in newly reptile-plagued Maine. A
good cast is given the challenge of keeping straight faces. (``Any
recent bear attacks?'' ``This was no bear. Bears don't attack
people underwater.'') And the horror effects can be divinely
cheesy, like the apparent underwater sprinkler hose whose churning
effect is described as ``scared perch.'' Trouble is, this story
also has to go through the motions of a totally familiar monster
plot. There's no way to make that seem anything but tired (Maslin).

   `MY LIFE SO FAR,' starring Colin Firth, Rosemary Harris, Irene
Jacob, Mary Elizabeth Mastrantonio, Malcolm McDowell and Robert
Norman. Directed by Hugh Hudson (PG-13, 93 minutes). A steady
``Masterpiece Theater''-like glow warms ``My Life So Far,'' a boy's
reverie of growing up in the misty Scottish highlands of Argyll in
the late 1920s. Frisky little Fraser (Norman), who narrates the
story, recalls a year in the life of the mildly troubled Macintosh
clan. What strife there is mostly involves his father, Edward
(Firth), an eccentric fiery-eyed inventor, and his Uncle Morris
(McDowell), who brings home a beautiful French wife (Ms. Jacob)
with whom Edward falls in love. If the story is slight, it is
smoothly told and well acted (especially by Firth) and the
nostalgic atmosphere is beguiling (Holden).

   `THE RED VIOLIN,' starring Samuel L. Jackson, Jason Flemying,
Greta Scacchi and Don McKellar. Directed by Francois Girard (not
rated, 130 minutes). ``The Red Violin'' follows the colorful
300-plus-year journey of a priceless violin from its construction
in an Italian workshop in 1681 to a contemporary auction in
Montreal. As it makes its way from Vienna to England to China, the
instrument becomes the inspiration for some richly photographed
historical tableaux. If the movie's narrative energy is undermined
by a plodding screenplay and wooden acting, the music, composed by
John Corigliano and played by Joshua Bell and the London
Philharmonia Orchestra, is sublime (Holden).

   nn

   `RUNAWAY BRIDE,' starring Julia Roberts and Richard Gere.
Directed by Garry Marshall (PG, 110 minutes). When the stars and
director first collaborated, on ``Pretty Woman,'' Ms. Roberts was
cast as an adorable Los Angeles streetwalker. Nine years later,
she's as far as she can get from Rodeo Drive, geographically and
otherwise. Playing the stern proprietor of a small-town Maryland
hardware store, she takes an awfully long while to slip from
scowling into flirtatious romantic-comedy mode. And when the sparks
start flying between her character and Gere's likably stubborn
newspaper columnist, they fly on cue. Funny minor characters and
one-liners offset the not-so-pretty story of a woman who habitually
jilts her men (Maslin).

   `SOUTH PARK: BIGGER, LONGER AND UNCUT,' with the voices of Trey
Parker, Matt Stone and Mary Kay Bergman. Directed by Parker (R, 88
minutes). The movie spinoff from the outrageous Comedy Central
cartoon series following the adventures of some potty-mouthed
third-grade boys in South Park, Colo., is extremely funny and
jubilantly obscene, with several sewers' worth of bathroom humor.
It is also a smart, pointed satire that demolishes the hypocrisy of
a conservative culture that allows almost unlimited violence and
gore in movies and on television but goes ballistic at the prospect
of children being exposed to dirty language and sexual
explicitness. When a group of tykes sneak into a Canadian movie
filled with obscenities and come home spewing smut, their parents
raise such a ruckus that the United States declares war on Canada.
Armageddon looms when the Devil, who has been having a troubled
affair with the recently deceased Saddam Hussein, decides to put in
an appearance. Contributing to the madness are 15 clever songs
spoofing everything from Rodgers and Hammerstein to ``Les
Miserables'' (Holden).

   `STAR WARS: EPISODE I _ THE PHANTOM MENACE,' starring Liam
Neeson, Ewan McGregor, Natalie Portman and Jake Lloyd. Directed by
George Lucas (PG-13, 132 minutes). Stripped of hype and breathless
expectations, Lucas' first installment offers a happy surprise:
It's up to snuff. It sustains the gee-whiz spirit of the series and
offers a swashbuckling extra-galactic getaway, creating illusions
that are even more plausible than the kitchen-raiding raptors of
``Jurassic Park.'' While the human stars here are indeed reduced to
playing action figures, they are upstaged by amazing backdrops and
hordes of crazily lifelike space beings as the Lewis Carroll in
Lucas is given free rein. The ``Star Wars'' franchise was funnier
and scrappier when it was new. But it simply wasn't capable of this
(Maslin).

   `TARZAN,' with the voices of Tony Goldwyn, Minnie Driver, Rosie
O'Donnell and Nigel Hawthorne. Directed by Kevin Lima and Chris
Buck (G, 88 minutes). No need to wonder how this animated Tarzan
movie could improve on the 47 others that preceded it. Disney
animation turns the hero into a supple, long-haired hunk, lets the
apes talk to him and whooshes through lush jungle settings with
exultant agility. This ``Tarzan'' is sprightly and likable in ways
that are hard to resist, with lively vocal performances, excitingly
kinetic animation and Phil Collins singing tunefully in the
background. Parents will stay awake, and children will be charmed
(Maslin).

   `TRICK,' starring Christian Campbell and John Paul Pitoc.
Directed by Jim Fall (R, 90 minutes). This engaging, tenderhearted
boy-meets-boy story features two handsome, doe-eyed actors in the
story of a romantic one-night stand. As in the Doris Day-era sex
comedies that are recalled here, the story is filled with obstacles
to the affair, the most noxious of them Tori Spelling in the role
of an incorrigible nuisance. Fall gives a small-town coziness to
his film's Greenwich Village settings and makes this a quaintly
likable date movie for audiences of any persuasion (Maslin).

   `TWIN FALLS IDAHO,' starring Michael and Mark Polish and Michele
Hicks. Directed by Michael Polish (R, 100 minutes). This eerily
effective film carries the real-life closeness of twin brothers
into the realm of haunting fantasy. The look-alike Polish siblings
play conjoined twins whose delicately balanced interdependence
yields a rare brand of tension. With a bleak, lonely look and a
strain of black humor (in their three-legged suit, the film's Falls
brothers impress everyone on Halloween), the film introduces a
wild, gorgeous young woman into their lives and watches what
happens when one twin starts to court her. The story is intensely
rendered, without gimmicks (Maslin).

   `WILD WILD WEST,' starring Will Smith, Kevin Kline, Kenneth
Branagh and Salma Hayek. Directed by Barry Sonnenfeld (PG-13, 107
minutes). Another big, lavish movie with no there there. This
post-Civil War James Bondish contraption-happy sci-fi film is hard
to categorize, a quality not to be confused with originality.
Directed by Sonnenfeld without the deadpan-alien sensibility that
worked for ``Men in Black,'' this stylistic grab bag is similarly
kinky but a lot more chaotic, however heroically Smith, as a newly
hunky and debonair action hero, tries to save the day. Good-looking
but dopey, with an emphasis on toylike but vaguely ghoulish special
effects. A movie with that much potential kiddie appeal didn't have
to start in a bordello, either (Maslin).

   Film Series

   `TO HAVE AND HAVE NOT.' Preparing to begin an 18-month survey of
its 17,000-title collection in October as part of the museumwide
exhibition ``MOMA 2000,'' the Museum of Modern Art is running a
77-film series that amounts to a wish list of films the museum
hopes to add to its collection. The series consists of films
regarded as significant in the development of cinema as a modern
art, including documentaries, experimental work and narrative
fiction films ranging from musicals to melodramas. This weekend's
attractions include the Scottish-born director Bill Forsyth's
comedy ``Local Hero'' (1983), with Burt Lancaster and Peter
Riegert, at 2 p.m. Saturday, followed at 5 p.m. by Martin
Scorsese's ``Goodfellas'' (1990), based on Nick Pileggi's book
``Wiseguy,'' about the life of a Mafioso. Continuing through Sept.
14 at New York's Museum of Modern Art, the series is free with
museum admission: $10 for adults, $6.50 for students and people 65
or older; free for visitors under 16 accompanied by an adult. Pay
what you wish on Fridays from 4:30 to 8:15 p.m. Screening
information: (212) 708-9400 (Van Gelder).

directed by Oliver Parker (PG-13, 97 minutes). The best thing about
Parker's likable but diluted screen adaptation of Oscar Wilde's
1895 comedy of politics and Victorian morality is Everett's
portrayal of Wilde's elegantly epigrammatic alter ego Lord Arthur
Goring. In underplaying this seemingly incorrigible (but actually
wise, witty and caring) rake, Everett makes him all the more
charming. Northam and Ms. Blanchett are well cast as a politician
and his priggish wife, but Ms. Moore and Ms. Driver miss hitting
the right notes in a screenplay that streamlines Wilde into a
quasi-contemporary style, keeping some but not all of the
playwright's scintillating bons mots. The settings are so lavish
they're almost edible (Holden).  

   `INSPECTOR GADGET,' starring Matthew Broderick and Rupert
Everett. Directed by David Kellogg (PG, 85 minutes). The midmorning
midden of children's cartoons that yielded a vein of cinematic gold
with ``George of the Jungle'' has now been mined for this clinker.
Too bad, because this Disney comedy wastes good talent. Broderick
brings an endearing combination of intelligence, wit and naivete to
his portrayal of a security guard who is transformed into the human
gizmo, Inspector Gadget, after being blown up in an effort to
capture a megalomaniacal magnate (Everett). But even Broderick can
go only so far with the film's noisy, childish material. Watching
this movie is like watching a human Swiss Army knife for nearly an
hour and a half. It's a remarkable device, but do you really want
to spend a lot of time with a not-too-bright hardware store
Frankenstein creation that can light cigars with his thumb, shoot a
grappling hook to the top of a skyscraper and produce a helicopter
from his head? (Lawrence Van Gelder).  

   `LAKE PLACID,' starring Bill Pullman, Bridget Fonda, Oliver
Platt and Brendan Gleeson. Written by David E. Kelley and directed
by Steve Miner (R, 88 minutes). Despite the DOA nature of the genre
it tacitly sends up, this ``Jaws''-minded demon crocodile movie
finds a fair amount to work with in newly reptile-plagued Maine. A
good cast is given the challenge of keeping straight faces. (``Any
recent bear attacks?'' ``This was no bear. Bears don't attack
people underwater.'') And the horror effects can be divinely
cheesy, like the apparent underwater sprinkler hose whose churning
effect is described as ``scared perch.'' Trouble is, this story
also has to go through the motions of a totally familiar monster
plot. There's no way to make that seem anything but tired (Maslin).

   `MY LIFE SO FAR,' starring Colin Firth, Rosemary Harris, Irene
Jacob, Mary Elizabeth Mastrantonio, Malcolm McDowell and Robert
Norman. Directed by Hugh Hudson (PG-13, 93 minutes). A steady
``Masterpiece Theater''-like glow warms ``My Life So Far,'' a boy's
reverie of growing up in the misty Scottish highlands of Argyll in
the late 1920s. Frisky little Fraser (Norman), who narrates the
story, recalls a year in the life of the mildly troubled Macintosh
clan. What strife there is mostly involves his father, Edward
(Firth), an eccentric fiery-eyed inventor, and his Uncle Morris
(McDowell), who brings home a beautiful French wife (Ms. Jacob)
with whom Edward falls in love. If the story is slight, it is
smoothly told and well acted (especially by Firth) and the
nostalgic atmosphere is beguiling (Holden).

   `THE RED VIOLIN,' starring Samuel L. Jackson, Jason Flemying,
Greta Scacchi and Don McKellar. Directed by Francois Girard (not
rated, 130 minutes). ``The Red Violin'' follows the colorful
300-plus-year journey of a priceless violin from its construction
in an Italian workshop in 1681 to a contemporary auction in
Montreal. As it makes its way from Vienna to England to China, the
instrument becomes the inspiration for some richly photographed
historical tableaux. If the movie's narrative energy is undermined
by a plodding screenplay and wooden acting, the music, composed by
John Corigliano and played by Joshua Bell and the London
Philharmonia Orchestra, is sublime (Holden).

   `RUNAWAY BRIDE,' starring Julia Roberts and Richard Gere.
Directed by Garry Marshall (PG, 110 minutes). When the stars and
director first collaborated, on ``Pretty Woman,'' Ms. Roberts was
cast as an adorable Los Angeles streetwalker. Nine years later,
she's as far as she can get from Rodeo Drive, geographically and
otherwise. Playing the stern proprietor of a small-town Maryland
hardware store, she takes an awfully long while to slip from
scowling into flirtatious romantic-comedy mode. And when the sparks
start flying between her character and Gere's likably stubborn
newspaper columnist, they fly on cue. Funny minor characters and
one-liners offset the not-so-pretty story of a woman who habitually
jilts her men (Maslin).

   `SOUTH PARK: BIGGER, LONGER AND UNCUT,' with the voices of Trey
Parker, Matt Stone and Mary Kay Bergman. Directed by Parker (R, 88
minutes). The movie spinoff from the outrageous Comedy Central
cartoon series following the adventures of some potty-mouthed
third-grade boys in South Park, Colo., is extremely funny and
jubilantly obscene, with several sewers' worth of bathroom humor.
It is also a smart, pointed satire that demolishes the hypocrisy of
a conservative culture that allows almost unlimited violence and
gore in movies and on television but goes ballistic at the prospect
of children being exposed to dirty language and sexual
explicitness. When a group of tykes sneak into a Canadian movie
filled with obscenities and come home spewing smut, their parents
raise such a ruckus that the United States declares war on Canada.
Armageddon looms when the Devil, who has been having a troubled
affair with the recently deceased Saddam Hussein, decides to put in
an appearance. Contributing to the madness are 15 clever songs
spoofing everything from Rodgers and Hammerstein to ``Les
Miserables'' (Holden).

   `STAR WARS: EPISODE I _ THE PHANTOM MENACE,' starring Liam
Neeson, Ewan McGregor, Natalie Portman and Jake Lloyd. Directed by
George Lucas (PG-13, 132 minutes). Stripped of hype and breathless
expectations, Lucas' first installment offers a happy surprise:
It's up to snuff. It sustains the gee-whiz spirit of the series and
offers a swashbuckling extra-galactic getaway, creating illusions
that are even more plausible than the kitchen-raiding raptors of
``Jurassic Park.'' While the human stars here are indeed reduced to
playing action figures, they are upstaged by amazing backdrops and
hordes of crazily lifelike space beings as the Lewis Carroll in
Lucas is given free rein. The ``Star Wars'' franchise was funnier
and scrappier when it was new. But it simply wasn't capable of this
(Maslin).

   `TARZAN,' with the voices of Tony Goldwyn, Minnie Driver, Rosie
O'Donnell and Nigel Hawthorne. Directed by Kevin Lima and Chris
Buck (G, 88 minutes). No need to wonder how this animated Tarzan
movie could improve on the 47 others that preceded it. Disney
animation turns the hero into a supple, long-haired hunk, lets the
apes talk to him and whooshes through lush jungle settings with
exultant agility. This ``Tarzan'' is sprightly and likable in ways
that are hard to resist, with lively vocal performances, excitingly
kinetic animation and Phil Collins singing tunefully in the
background. Parents will stay awake, and children will be charmed
(Maslin).

   `TRICK,' starring Christian Campbell and John Paul Pitoc.
Directed by Jim Fall (R, 90 minutes). This engaging, tenderhearted
boy-meets-boy story features two handsome, doe-eyed actors in the
story of a romantic one-night stand. As in the Doris Day-era sex
comedies that are recalled here, the story is filled with obstacles
to the affair, the most noxious of them Tori Spelling in the role
of an incorrigible nuisance. Fall gives a small-town coziness to
his film's Greenwich Village settings and makes this a quaintly
likable date movie for audiences of any persuasion (Maslin).

   `TWIN FALLS IDAHO,' starring Michael and Mark Polish and Michele
Hicks. Directed by Michael Polish (R, 100 minutes). This eerily
effective film carries the real-life closeness of twin brothers
into the realm of haunting fantasy. The look-alike Polish siblings
play conjoined twins whose delicately balanced interdependence
yields a rare brand of tension. With a bleak, lonely look and a
strain of black humor (in their three-legged suit, the film's Falls
brothers impress everyone on Halloween), the film introduces a
wild, gorgeous young woman into their lives and watches what
happens when one twin starts to court her. The story is intensely
rendered, without gimmicks (Maslin).

   `WILD WILD WEST,' starring Will Smith, Kevin Kline, Kenneth
Branagh and Salma Hayek. Directed by Barry Sonnenfeld (PG-13, 107
minutes). Another big, lavish movie with no there there. This
post-Civil War James Bondish contraption-happy sci-fi film is hard
to categorize, a quality not to be confused with originality.
Directed by Sonnenfeld without the deadpan-alien sensibility that
worked for ``Men in Black,'' this stylistic grab bag is similarly
kinky but a lot more chaotic, however heroically Smith, as a newly
hunky and debonair action hero, tries to save the day. Good-looking
but dopey, with an emphasis on toylike but vaguely ghoulish special
effects. A movie with that much potential kiddie appeal didn't have
to start in a bordello, either (Maslin).

   Film Series

   `TO HAVE AND HAVE NOT.' Preparing to begin an 18-month survey of
its 17,000-title collection in October as part of the museumwide
exhibition ``MOMA 2000,'' the Museum of Modern Art is running a
77-film series that amounts to a wish list of films the museum
hopes to add to its collection. The series consists of films
regarded as significant in the development of cinema as a modern
art, including documentaries, experimental work and narrative
fiction films ranging from musicals to melodramas. This weekend's
attractions include the Scottish-born director Bill Forsyth's
comedy ``Local Hero'' (1983), with Burt Lancaster and Peter
Riegert, at 2 p.m. Saturday, followed at 5 p.m. by Martin
Scorsese's ``Goodfellas'' (1990), based on Nick Pileggi's book
``Wiseguy,'' about the life of a Mafioso. Continuing through Sept.
14 at New York's Museum of Modern Art, the series is free with
museum admission: $10 for adults, $6.50 for students and people 65
or older; free for visitors under 16 accompanied by an adult. Pay
what you wish on Fridays from 4:30 to 8:15 p.m. Screening
information: (212) 708-9400 (Van Gelder).
